Chris Croome <chris@...> writes:

> Hi
> 
> On Wed 26-Feb-2003 at 11:23:07AM +0000, Nic Ferrier wrote:
> >
> > My experience of HTTP authentication is that the fixed user
> > interface makes it unpopular with users (or at least website
> > designers) and that has a knock on effect on the architecture of
> > web services components built as part of the same application.
> 
> I think the biggest problem with HTTP Authentication is that no web
> browser has a 'logout' function and the worst thing about this is
> that if you type the wrong password you then have to close your
> browser before trying again.
> 
> This is the bugzilla entry for this:
> 
>   http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=55181

It's a long time since I dealt with basic auth... but I thought it was
possible to send the UNAUTHORIZED response to log the user out and
then have the user log in again with another username and password.

The problem with that is again the crappy UI. If the browser always
displayed the entity "facilitating" the authentication (ie: the entity
in the UNAUTHORIZED response) then the user could have a clear logout
that worked as they expect it to.


Does that make sense?


Nic
